name: Fancy
body:
### Welcome to Fancy.
Fancy is a new dynamic, pure object-oriented programming language for the [Rubinius VM](http://rubini.us).
It is heavily inspired by Smalltalk, Ruby, Io and Erlang.
Fancy has built-in support for concurrency via the actor model, similar to Io or Erlang and allows you to use almost any Ruby library out there, including most C extensions.


### Installation
This will get you going with the latest and greatest version of Fancy:

```
$ git clone https://github.com/bakkdoor/fancy.git
$ cd fancy
$ rake
```

Start it up!

```
$ bin/fancy
```

Or run the test suite:

```
$ bin/fancy bin/fspec
```

For your convenience make sure to add Fancy's `bin` directory to your `$PATH` environment variable:

```
export PATH=$PATH:/path/to/fancy/bin
```

If you prefer using an official release, you can install Fancy as a Ruby gem, just make sure you're running it via Rubinius:

```
$ rbx -S gem install fancy
```

Or use rvm / rbenv:

```
$ rvm install rbx
$ rvm use rbx
$ gem install fancy
```


### Libraries / Examples
There are a bunch of (somewhat unrealistic) code examples in the [examples](https://github.com/bakkdoor/fancy/tree/master/examples) directory. 
Also, here's a list of libraries / repositories (Fancy packages) you can install and play with:

* [Redis client](https://github.com/bakkdoor/redis.fy)
* [Sinatra web development for Fancy](https://github.com/rkh/sinatra.fy)
* [MessagePack serialization / RPC](https://github.com/bakkdoor/msgpack.fy)
* [IRC client / IRC bots](https://github.com/bakkdoor/fancy_irc)
* [Sample link shortener service with sinatra.fy and redis.fy](https://github.com/bakkdoor/shortefy)
* [Fancy DSL for Twitter's Storm (WIP)](https://github.com/bakkdoor/stormify)

And some utility repositories:

* [Snippets for Fancy's Emacs mode](https://github.com/bakkdoor/fancy-snippets)
* [VIM mode for Fancy](https://github.com/nuclearsandwich/fancy-vim)
tagline: A dynamic, pure object-oriented programming language inspired by Smalltalk, Ruby, Io and Erlang that runs on the Rubinius VM.
